Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Kinematic and Mechanical Alignment in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Ninety-nine primary TKAs for osteoarthritis were randomised

Participants.evidence: Ninety-nine primary TKAs for osteoarthritis were randomised to mechanical alignment (n = 50) or kinematic alignment (n = 49) groups.

Intervention.evidence: Computer navigation was used for mechanical alignment, and patient-specific cutting blocks for kinematic alignment.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare kinematic alignment with mechanical alignment in total knee arthroplasty (TKA) regarding patient-reported outcomes, survivorship, and radiographic aseptic loosening over five years.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was patient-reported outcome measures assessed using the Knee Society Score, VAS, Oxford Knee Score, WOMAC, Forgotten Joint Score, and EuroQol 5D at five years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ninety-nine primary TKAs for osteoarthritis were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: At five years, 95% of mechanical alignment and 96% of kinematic alignment TKAs were available for follow-up.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean Oxford Knee Score was similar (kinematic: 41.4 ± 7.2 vs. mechanical: 41.7 ± 6.3; difference -0.3 [95% CI -3.2 to 2.5]; p = 0.99).

Harms.evidence: One case of radiographic aseptic loosening was observed in the mechanical alignment group.
